sentences.sentence: By Peter SubissatiMany adjectives have been used to qualify Pope Francis' whirlwind visit to Iraq.

While most have opted for "historic," "belated" is perhaps more apt, for it comes precisely when much of Middle Eastern Christendom is on its knees.One of the most powerful images of the visit occurred when Pope Francis addressed his flock from the bombed-out carcass of a church destroyed by ISIL.

The choice of Mosul could not have been more symbolic, as the formerly vibrant city, which once stood at the ancient crossroads of cultures and religions, is now an ethnically homogenous city in ruins.The tragic fate of the beleaguered Christians of Mosul is not constrained to the city's old quarters.
Persecution and violence against Christians have also struck in their historic heartland of the Nineveh Plains, as they have throughout Iraq.

That the country's Christian population has plummeted from 1.5 million to just 250,000 in less than two decades speaks volumes about the state of pluralism in Iraq.This, however, is not without precedent.
Christians need only look to the 1950s and the fate of Iraq's now non-existent Jewish community.

The main difference, and this comes without consolation, is that the plight of Christians is a more drawn-out affair.Iraq is but a microcosm of what has befallen Christians throughout the Middle East.
Just a century ago, Christians represented 20 per cent of the region's population.
Today, they represent a mere four per cent.

In absolute terms, the number of Christians has steadily eroded in every country with historic populations except for Israel, Jordan and Lebanon, where the Christian population has grown because of the influx of refugees from neighbouring Syria.Throughout the region, it is the same story again, just with a different cast.

Aleppo, Alexandria, Baghdad, Cairo, Damascus, Istanbul, Izmir, Tehran, and even tiny Bethlehem, the birthplace of Jesus, all of which, over millennia, teemed with Jewish life, now serve as backdrops to Middle Eastern Christianity's long dÃ©nouement.A building is illuminated with a picture of Pope Francis with Iraq's top Shi'ite cleric, Grand Ayatollah Ali al-Sistani, in Baghdad, Iraq on March 7, 2021.Although some hope derives from Pope Francis' address in the ancient ruins of Ur, where he was flanked by clergy from Iraq's Christian, Shiite, Sunni, Mandaean and Yazidi communities, it will take more than platitudes condemning extremism to alter the course of Christianity's expulsion from its historic homeland.
The pointed symbolism of an interfaith ceremony of monotheistic religions in Abraham's native Ur without a representative from the Jewish faith is telling.

But, then again, what was once the Middle East's largest Jewish community, one dating back 2,500 years and numbering some 150,000 souls, including nearly 40 per cent of Baghdad's population, has since been eradicated and reduced to four people.The only viable way to ensure the long-term vitality of Christians in the region is with major changes at both ends of the societal pyramid.
Middle Eastern leaders must acknowledge - and end - their role in stoking sectarian conflict and persecution.
For decades, it has been expedient for even the most enlightened despot to mitigate public discontent by scapegoating minorities and empowering religious extremists.
Thankfully, the youthful throngs who have taken to the streets in recent memory are better educated and more widely exposed to the outside world.

They must continue to press for democratic reforms that enable civil society to take root and flourish.Raymond J. de Souza: Despite pandemic, Pope Francis reaches out to Christians and Muslims in Iraq(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/raymond-j-de-souza-despite-pandemic-pope-francis-reaches-out-to-christians-and-muslims-in-iraq)Avi Benlolo: Hey, Roger Waters, 2018 called.

It wants it threadbare anti-Israel rhetoric back(https://nationalpost.com/opinion/avi-benlolo-hey-roger-waters-2018-called-it-wants-it-threadbare-anti-israel-rhetoric-back)Of course, that is wishful thinking, and history tragically reminds us that, however bright the horizon, it is unwise to don rose-coloured shades under the blinding sun of the Middle East.As the cradle of our common Judeo-Christian civilization continues to hemorrhage Christians, Western nations should seize Pope Francis' courageous, albeit belated, historic visit, and forcefully condemn the persecution and erasure of Christians in the Middle East.

Leaders who value freedom of thought, choice, and belief must speak with a unified voice and demand concrete political reforms aimed at protecting and empowering religious minorities.There is an old Arabic adage: "first comes Saturday, then comes Sunday."

While it's too late for the Jews of Iraq, it's just a quarter past midnight on Sunday for most Christians in the Middle East.With our action, they need not suffer the same fate.Peter Subissati is Associate Director of Communications at the Centre for Israel and Jewish Affairs (CIJA)?
